biogHist.abstract:
The Australian-Migrant Women's Association was established by Dorothy Buckland-Fuller in 1974 to bring together immigrant and Australian-born women to discuss matters of common interest. Buckland-Fuller, who had some influence within the Greek community in New South Wales, was concerned that Greek women were often too inward looking. She wanted to expose them to new ideas and open lines of communication between them and other women of culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds.
Buckland-Fuller was assisted by International Women's Year funding in 1975 to promote the initiative. She received a small grant to assist in running a program of monthly meetings as the premises of the Greek Orthodox Community of New South Wales in Sydney. These meetings brought together about one hundred women at a time from different ethnic communities, as well as Buckland-Fuller's friends from the Women's Electoral Lobby and academic circles.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Being Seen And Heard: Migrant Women Organising In Australia, A Documentary History (2006 - )
International Women's Year National Advisory Committee (1974 - 1976)

descriptiveNote.p: The International Women's Year National Advisory Committee supported the Australian-Migrant Women's Association by providing important seed-funding in its first year of operation.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: 'Australian-Migrant Women's Association', in The Australian Women's Register, National Foundation for Australian Women and The University of Melbourne
Book Section: Double Disadvantage: Migrant and Aboriginal Women

archref.unittitle: Papers of the Greek Orthodox Community of New South Wales
archref.abstract:
The archival holdings are organised in the following collections: 1 Private Collections 2 Archives of the Community 3 Printed Material 4 History of organisations 5 Photographic material 6 Visual aids 7 Recordings of events 8 Ecclesiastical items 9 Costumes 10 Library
Women's committee material can be found in the archives of the community

physdesc.physfacet: Mainly paper documents, although there is some ephemera and heritage material, and photographs.
